name: A Violent History of Benevolence: The Deck
description: A complete tarot deck examining interlocking oppressions in social work history, enriched with indigenous wisdom, spiritual practices, and contemporary voices. Not a 1-1 mapping—there are always cracks in the systems.

methodology.source_text: Chapman & Withers (2019). A Violent History of Benevolence
methodology.core_principle: All figures are complicit. Decolonization might be more about grandmothers than about perpetuating different versions of the standard account.
methodology.structure: Archetypal resonances, not strict assignments. Cracks in the system.

suits.standard_account: Figures from the canonical social work history
suits.erased_voices: Those systematically marginalized in social work historiography
suits.the_cracks: Indigenous wisdom, spiritual practices, everyday roles
suits.contemporary_witnesses: Those doing social working today in different ways

cards.name: Jane Addams
cards.context: Hull-House founder, Nobel laureate, eugenics supporter. High morals embedded in colonial institutions.
cards.reflection: What violences hide behind moral authority?

cards.name: Mary Richmond
cards.context: Created 'scientific casework'—the architecture of professional social control.
cards.reflection: When does structure become a cage?

cards.name: Katherine Bement Davis
cards.context: Bedford Hills Reformatory superintendent. Built institutions to confine 'defective' women for life.
cards.reflection: What fears drive policies that claim to be rational?

cards.name: Josephine Shaw Lowell
cards.context: COS founder who led eugenic criminology while supporting labor rights.
cards.reflection: How do we reckon with those who did both harm and good?

cards.name: Richard Henry Pratt
cards.context: 'Kill the Indian, save the man.' Founded Carlisle Indian School.
cards.reflection: What bondage presents itself as education?

cards.name: Albert Rose
cards.context: Wrote the report that destroyed Africville. Called Regent Park a failure.
cards.reflection: What dies when experts decide communities must be 'renewed'?

cards.name: Abraham Flexner
cards.context: Professionalization of medicine and social work. Racist medical models.
cards.reflection: Who decides what counts as professional knowledge?

cards.name: Oscar McCulloch
cards.context: His study launched eugenic policy—then he changed his mind, too late.
cards.reflection: What cycles of harm continue from research done with good intentions?

cards.name: J.J. Kelso
cards.context: Architect of Canada's Children's Aid Society. Aimed to convert Catholic children to Protestantism.
cards.reflection: Whose children are 'saved'? From what? For whom?

cards.name: Jeffery Brackett
cards.context: Credited with coining the term 'social work'—orderly, responsible, disciplined.
cards.reflection: What is named into existence? What is named out?

cards.name: Simon Patten
cards.context: Coined 'social worker' in 1900. Believed the poor needed training in proper consumption.
cards.reflection: Who teaches whom how to live?

cards.name: Philip C. Garrett
cards.context: Chaired the 1892 conference where Pratt spoke. Nearly invisible now.
cards.reflection: What world was built on erased foundations?

cards.name: Theodore Roosevelt
cards.context: Eugenicist president whose nomination Addams seconded.
cards.reflection: What does 'progress' require? Whose bodies?

cards.name: Sir Francis Galton
cards.context: Coined 'eugenics' in 1883. The word that named a genocide.
cards.reflection: What words do we coin that will be condemned?

cards.name: John Edward Lloyd
cards.context: 'Sometimes people need to be shown what's in their best interests.'
cards.quote: Sometimes people need to be shown what's in their best interests.
cards.reflection: Who decides what's best for whom?

cards.name: Reverend William Baldwin
cards.context: Advocated hard work and strict discipline as 'the best means of getting rid of the professional vagrant.'
cards.reflection: What would it mean to 'get rid of' poverty without getting rid of the poor?

cards.name: Emma Goldman
cards.context: Anarchist revolutionary who was also a eugenicist. Contradictions all the way down.
cards.reflection: What blind spots hide in our most radical visions?

cards.name: Ida B. Wells
cards.context: Documented terror when doing so meant death threats. Published Southern Horrors.
cards.reflection: What truth requires courage to speak in your context?

cards.name: W.E.B. Du Bois
cards.context: Radical activism, scholarly rigor. Spoke at Hull-House while critiquing its limits.
cards.reflection: What does it mean to work within institutions you're critiquing?

cards.name: Maggie L. Walker
cards.context: First woman bank president in America. Made something from nothing within hostile systems.
cards.reflection: What resources do you have that systems refuse to recognize?

cards.name: Zaynab al-Ghazali
cards.context: Founded Muslim Women's Association. Imprisoned and tortured for organizing.
cards.reflection: What becomes visible only from a position of surrender?

cards.name: Janie Porter Barrett
cards.context: Founded first Black settlement house in Virginia from her own home.
cards.reflection: What grows from care that refuses institutional recognition?

cards.name: Mary Ann Shadd Cary
cards.context: First Black woman newspaper editor in North America. Voice of the fugitive.
cards.reflection: What hope sustains when the journey has no guaranteed end?

cards.name: George Edmund Haynes
cards.context: Co-founded Urban League. Built institutions to address inequality within systems that created it.
cards.reflection: Can justice be built within unjust institutions?

cards.name: Reverdy Cassius Ransom
cards.context: AME Bishop who brought social gospel to Black churches. Christian socialist.
cards.reflection: What wisdom comes from standing apart from mainstream success?

cards.name: Henry Bibb
cards.context: Escaped slavery multiple times trying to free his family. Founded Voice of the Fugitive.
cards.reflection: What would you risk everything to return to?

cards.name: Booker T. Washington
cards.context: Accommodation politics—the middle path that critics called complicity.
cards.reflection: When is patience wisdom? When is it collaboration?

cards.name: Frederick Douglass
cards.context: Self-liberated, self-educated, self-made. Supported feminism.
cards.reflection: What does it mean to make yourself when the world unmakes you?

cards.name: Claudette Colvin
cards.context: At 15, refused to give up her bus seat—nine months before Rosa Parks. A teenage mom.
cards.reflection: Whose determination is remembered? Whose is erased?

cards.name: Rosa Parks
cards.context: Trained NAACP organizer. The staged action that sparked a movement.
cards.reflection: What gets remembered as spontaneous that was actually organized?

cards.name: Viola Desmond
cards.context: Sat in whites-only section in Nova Scotia, 1946. Now on the Canadian $10 bill.
cards.reflection: What joy is an act of resistance?

cards.name: Aaron 'Pa' Carvery
cards.context: Final holdout in Africville, refusing to leave until 1970.
cards.reflection: What does it mean to hold ground when the world insists you move?

cards.name: Elizabeth Williams Shadd Shreve
cards.context: Circuit-riding missionary in Buxton fugitive settlement. Nearly invisible to history.
cards.reflection: Whose knowledge sustains communities while remaining unwritten?

cards.name: Bayard Rustin
cards.context: Organized the March on Washington. Erased for being gay.
cards.reflection: What work happens behind the scenes? Who gets credited?

cards.name: James Baldwin
cards.context: Writer, witness, exile. 'Not everything that is faced can be changed, but nothing can be changed until it is faced.'
cards.quote: Not everything that is faced can be changed, but nothing can be changed until it is faced.
cards.reflection: What are you refusing to face?

cards.name: Huey Newton
cards.context: Co-founded Black Panther Party. Free breakfast programs as revolutionary praxis.
cards.reflection: What does it mean to feed people as an act of revolution?

cards.name: Malcolm X
cards.context: Transformation upon transformation. Assassinated before Africville was emptied.
cards.reflection: What would it mean to change your mind completely?

cards.name: Martin Luther King Jr
cards.context: The sanitized dream vs. the radical reality. Assassinated before Africville was emptied.
cards.reflection: What parts of your heroes have been sanitized?

cards.name: Mohandas Gandhi
cards.context: Troubling relationship with 'untouchable' caste. Contradictions.
cards.reflection: What contradictions do our heroes carry?

cards.name: Ernesto 'Che' Guevara
cards.context: The river crossing metaphor. Symbolic radicalization. Icon on t-shirts.
cards.reflection: What does it mean to 'cross to the other side' when there is no other side?

cards.name: The Grandmother
cards.context: As Bayo Akomolafe says, decolonization might be more about grandmothers than about systems.
cards.quote: Decolonization might be more about grandmothers.
cards.reflection: What did your grandmother know that no institution taught?

cards.name: The Mother
cards.context: The work that holds the world together. Never counted in GDP.
cards.reflection: What labor is invisible because it is constant?

cards.name: The Friend
cards.context: The one who shows up. No professional boundary. No billing code.
cards.reflection: Who shows up for you without being paid?

cards.name: The Doula
cards.context: Holding space at thresholds. Birth and death doulas. The ancient role.
cards.reflection: Who holds space for you at thresholds?

cards.name: Preto Velho
cards.context: Spirit of enslaved African elders in Umbanda. Slow wisdom. Pipe smoke. Patience earned through suffering.
cards.reflection: What wisdom comes only through suffering that should never have been?

cards.name: Caboclo
cards.context: Indigenous ancestral spirits in Umbanda. Warriors and healers. The forest's knowledge.
cards.reflection: What knowledge lives in the land that was stolen?

cards.name: Pai de Santo / Mãe de Santo
cards.context: Father/Mother of the saints. Keeper of Axé. Community anchor.
cards.reflection: What communities anchor you that no institution recognizes?

cards.name: The Neighbor Who Brings Food
cards.context: The ethics Addams admired in poor communities: 'the ready outflow of sympathy and material assistance.'
cards.reflection: When did someone just show up with what you needed?

cards.name: The Child Who Asks Why
cards.context: The one who asks the obvious question that no one else will ask.
cards.reflection: What obvious question are you afraid to ask?

cards.name: Bayo Akomolafe
cards.context: 'The times are urgent; let us slow down.' Nigerian philosopher, psychologist, professor.
cards.quote: The times are urgent; let us slow down.
cards.reflection: What becomes possible when you stop trying to fix?

cards.name: Vanessa Andreotti
cards.context: Hospicing modernity. 'We cannot continue to consume the world and expect different results.'
cards.reflection: What needs to die so something else can live?

cards.name: Josh Shrei
cards.context: The Emerald podcast. Remembering what was almost forgotten. Ancestral practices.
cards.reflection: What have you almost forgotten that wants to be remembered?

cards.name: Sam Harris
cards.context: Bringing meditation to secular spaces. Also: contradictions and controversies.
cards.reflection: What wisdom traditions get extracted and repackaged?

cards.name: Neil deGrasse Tyson
cards.context: Making science accessible. Wonder as public education.
cards.reflection: What knowledge do you make accessible? What do you gatekeep?

cards.name: Luiza Lian
cards.context: Brazilian artist weaving ancestral wisdom through contemporary sound.
cards.reflection: What ancestral wisdom moves through your art, your work, your body?

reading_instructions.single_card: Draw one card. Sit with the figure, their context, their contradictions. What reflection arises?
reading_instructions.three_card: Past complicity / Present reckoning / Future possibility
reading_instructions.full_spread: The River: Draw 7 cards. This is not two sides. These are all tributaries of the same river.

attribution.source: Chapman, C., & Withers, A. J. (2019). A Violent History of Benevolence.
attribution.created_with: Claude (Anthropic AI) via Claude Code CLI
attribution.note: All figures are complicit. There is no other side of the river.
